body_html:
w is not a variable, it's a Tensor. w.name gives the Tensor's name, but v.name returns the variable's name as you would see in the checkpoint. independently, you can do: with variable_scope(...) as varscope: create_variables with variable_scope(varscope, reuse=True): reuse variables via get_variable
…
On Thu, Dec 8, 2016 at 10:45 AM, Nasim Rahaman ***@***.***> wrote: I ran another test (on @michaelisard <https://github.com/michaelisard> 's advice): with tf.name_scope('layer123') as scope: v = tf.Variable(3., name='v') with tf.name_scope('layer123'): w = v * 2 print(w.name) # still prints 'layer123_1/mul:0' Replacing the first name_scope with variable_scope and Variable with get_variable did not change anything. However, I've found this works: with tf.name_scope('layer123') as scope: v = tf.Variable(3., name='v') with tf.name_scope(scope): w = v * 2 print(w.name) # prints 'layer123/mul:0' like it should This is quite unsatisfactory, for obvious reasons (e.g. get_variable functionality is rendered useless, etc.). — You are receiving this because you were mentioned. body_text:
w is not a variable, it's a Tensor.  w.name gives the Tensor's name, but
v.name returns the variable's name as you would see in the checkpoint.

independently, you can do:

with variable_scope(...) as varscope:
   create_variables

with variable_scope(varscope, reuse=True):
   reuse variables via get_variable
…
On Thu, Dec 8, 2016 at 10:45 AM, Nasim Rahaman ***@***.***> wrote:
 I ran another test (on @michaelisard <https://github.com/michaelisard> 's
 advice):

 with tf.name_scope('layer123') as scope:
     v = tf.Variable(3., name='v')
     with tf.name_scope('layer123'):
     w = v * 2
 print(w.name)    # still prints 'layer123_1/mul:0'

 Replacing the first name_scope with variable_scope and Variable with
 get_variable did not change anything. However, I've found this works:

 with tf.name_scope('layer123') as scope:
     v = tf.Variable(3., name='v')
 with tf.name_scope(scope):
     w = v * 2
 print(w.name)    # prints 'layer123/mul:0' like it should

 This is quite unsatisfactory, for obvious reasons (e.g. get_variable
 functionality is rendered useless, etc.).

 —
 You are receiving this because you were mentioned.

body:
w is not a variable, it's a Tensor.  w.name gives the Tensor's name, but
v.name returns the variable's name as you would see in the checkpoint.

independently, you can do:

with variable_scope(...) as varscope:
   create_variables

with variable_scope(varscope, reuse=True):
   reuse variables via get_variable


On Thu, Dec 8, 2016 at 10:45 AM, Nasim Rahaman <notifications@github.com>
wrote:

>     w = v * 2
> print(w.name)    # still prints 'layer123_1/mul:0'
>
> Replacing the first name_scope with variable_scope and Variable with
> get_variable did not change anything. However, I've found this works:
>
> with tf.name_scope('layer123') as scope:
>     v = tf.Variable(3., name='v')
> with tf.name_scope(scope):
>     w = v * 2
> print(w.name)    # prints 'layer123/mul:0' like it should
>
> This is quite unsatisfactory, for obvious reasons (e.g. get_variable
> functionality is rendered useless, etc.).
